column4: hello.  i have a file name "libstdc++.so.5".  if i want to "install" this library on my system, can I just put it in "/lib/" or "/usr/lib/", or do I have to configure something, or what?
it is best to install the entire package. however, it _might_ work if you add it to /usr/lib and then do depmod -a
i don't have a debian package, i just have the file
my guess is you will need the rest of the files in that package for your desired affect. the deb does exist, you may need to put backports in your sources.list, but it exists

aplund: there is no package.  it's just this file.  i'm trying to install the intel fortran compiler (because gfortran just doesn't work very well).  it says that i need to install libstdc++.so.5, and so i'm trying to figure out how to do so
I'll betcha as soon as you figure out how to feed that to gfortran it will ask you for another file =p
you mean feed that to the intel compiler?  perhaps, but this is "step 1", i guess...
have you tried putting it in /usr/lib and running depmod -a?
i didn't do "depmod -a" -- not sure what that does
nm. I'm thinking of something else. depmod is for kernel modules
you'll want to run that before you try and use the .so, wherever you decide to put it
so your problem is the INSTALLER wants that file, correct?
and the install still breaks after exporting tht path? with the same error?
yep, as if i had done nothing differently
I know aplund doesn't think it wise, but it may be looking for it in a set path like /usr/lib.  I'd try if it were me, but that's me.
actually i already tried this before coming here...
